awd_titl_txt: Early Detection of Solar Flares Using High Sensitivity Extreme-UltraViolet (EUV) Data
awd_abstract_narration:
The timely detection of solar flares is of primary importance to space weather forecasting efforts that are critical to national security, the economy, infrastructure services, remote sensing, space exploration, navigation, and timing services -- as stated in the National Space Weather Strategy and Action Plan.  Current flare detection methods have a built-in minimum 4-minute delay in their alert issuance due to the limitations of the methods and instruments used.  However, a new flare detection method using high-sensitivity satellite data has been developed that improves flare detection time significantly.  This new data and tool allows preventative measures to take place in a timely manner to protect societal and national interests.  Furthermore, it has a significant potential to contribute to the current understanding of solar flare initiation processes -- a highly debated scientific subject.

Currently, solar flare forecasting methods primarily rely on X-ray irradiance data without any visual imagery.  The main goal of this three-year project is to take advantage of the new, high-sensitivity, real-time, low-latency data available from the GOES/Solar Ultraviolet Imager (SUVI) instrument in order to identify not only the time of the flare occurrence, but its location as well -- a property that can influence the magnitude of the corresponding space weather effects.  Furthermore, the new tool is capable of giving over ten minutes of advance warning before detrimental space weather effects occur.  The high-sensitivity extreme ultraviolet data available to us is uniquely suitable to identify early signs of a flare development using the novel, robust and fast flare detection tool to be utilized during this project.  By analyzing the flare development process the algorithm could also gain insight into how early ultraviolet signatures are related to flare magnitudes.  It also provides a brand new insight into the deeper physics of flares and the ways in which energy is released and plasma is heated during the evolution of energetic solar eruptions.  Studying the temporal development of flares in different wavelengths allows us to better understand how the initiation happens and what different physical environments and processes lead to instabilities in flaring regions and how it relates to the magnitude of severe space weather disturbances.  The research and EPO agenda of this project supports the Strategic Goals of the AGS Division in discovery, learning, diversity, and interdisciplinary research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This work presents a comprehensive research study focused on understanding and identifying precursors to solar flares using the Detection and EUV Flare Tracking (DEFT) tool. The research aims to improve space weather forecasting by leveraging the information contained within extreme ultraviolet (EUV) observations of the Sun, specifically focusing on small-scale magnetic reconnection events that manifest as EUV brightenings.

The DEFT tool is a crucial component of this research, as it offers an automated, fast, and consistent method to identify EUV precursors. This automated process is designed to minimize computational overhead, allowing for efficient analysis of large datasets. The tool utilizes data from the GOES/SUVI 304 Å observations, a specific wavelength of EUV light, to detect, group, and analyze sudden impulses that potentially precede solar flares.

The core of the study revolves around analyzing precursor signatures leading up to hundreds of solar flares, encompassing C, M, and X class flares observed between 2017 and the present. The findings reveal a strong correlation between the presence of EUV precursors and the occurrence of solar flares. Notably, precursors were detected for 93% of the studied flares within a six-hour window prior to the flare's onset.

To further analyze the relationship, a superposed epoch analysis was conducted. This technique revealed that elevated precursor activity tended to occur across all magnitudes of flares in the two hours immediately preceding the flare. This finding reinforces the idea that these EUV signatures are not merely random occurrences, but rather indicative of processes directly leading to flare initiation.

The study also investigated the frequency of precursors in relation to flare magnitude. It was observed that the frequency of precursors gradually increases before M-class flares, but decreases for C-class flares. This suggests that the processes leading to stronger flares are more pronounced and potentially involve a more sustained build-up of magnetic energy, reflected in the increased precursor activity.

Furthermore, the analysis revealed that in the 20 minutes leading up to a flare, there is a significantly higher precursor frequency, pixel count, and power associated with M-class flares compared to C-class flares. This observation further reinforces the idea that M-class flares are preceded by more intense and energetic precursor activity.

We propose that the observed EUV precursors are the observable signatures of small-scale magnetic reconnection events. These events, occurring in the corona, release energy that manifests as EUV brightenings. The consistently increasing frequency of these precursors suggests that the region is becoming increasingly unstable and approaching a critical point that culminates in flare initiation.

We emphasize the importance of continued research on EUV precursors. A deeper understanding of the processes that build and reduce magnetic instability prior to the main-stage flare is crucial for improving forecasting capabilities. The consistent and reliable detection and differentiation of EUV precursors, as enabled by the DEFT tool, could significantly enhance current flare forecasting efforts.
